ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

POLYTECHNIC FEE REVISION FOR PERMANENT RESIDENTS AND INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS

     1.  Mrs Josephine Teo asked the Minister for Education whether the recent fee revision for permanent residents and international students studying in polytechnics gives the impression that Singapore is no longer as welcoming to foreign students in our institutes of higher learning.

     The Minister for Education (Dr Ng Eng Hen):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the fee increases for Singapore Permanent Residents (PRs) and international students (IS) attending our polytechnics are appropriate as they reflect a differentiation between Singapore Citizens, Permanent Residents (PRs) and foreigners.  Even after the increases, polytechnic fee at about $13,000 for a three-year course to obtain a diploma still remains highly subsidised and competitive.  Let me just give two examples to illustrate, just for comparison.  The first example: international students studying in Hong Kong pay as much as around $18,000 to attain an associate degree, which is quite similar to our polytechnic diploma. Similarly, courses which lead to foundation degrees in UK cost up to $52,000.  So, $13,000 for a polytechnic diploma as compared to Hong Kong and the UK.


 

         Prospective students would know that our polytechnics offer a high quality of education and industry-relevant training.  More importantly, to signal that we still welcome PRs and IS into the polytechnics, there are, in place, readily available financial loan assistance schemes to help these PR students and international students.

     Mrs Josephine Teo (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, one supplementary

Column: 2354

question.  I would like to ask the Minister how far the fee differentiation is likely to go.  In the UK, international students may pay three to four times the fees paid by the local students, whereas in Australia the difference could be even sharper, sometimes five to six times higher.  Does the Minister foresee fee differentiation in Singapore between the local and the foreign students going as far as in the UK and Australia?

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I would not preclude any further changes but, generally, our philosophy is that we want to keep a differentiation between citizens and PRs and international students.  Yet, at the same time, we are also aware of the competitiveness of our polytechnics and our universities in attracting students.  So, we do not have a fixed timeline and fees for all institutions are reviewed from time to time.  And if we feel that the market signals are correct as well as that it continues to be competitive and as the costs of education go up, there may be adjustments from time to time.

Column: 2354

SOCIAL STUDIES AS A SUBJECT IN SCHOOLS

(Inclusion of more topics on Singapore's art and culture)

     2.  Ms Audrey Wong Wai Yen asked the Minister for Education with the proposal to expand Social Studies as a subject in schools (a) whether the subject will include more topics on Singapore's arts and culture, covering both traditional and contemporary arts; and (b) whether the Ministry will consider additional schemes to promote the understanding and appreciation of traditional Asian arts among students and teachers.  

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, in our primary and secondary school

Column: 2355

curriculum, Art and Music are the key subjects to develop our students’ understanding and appreciation of traditional and contemporary Asian arts. Through the primary and secondary Art curriculum, students are exposed to artworks, techniques and materials unique to various Asian cultures and contemporary artists.  Students are taught basic batik techniques, Chinese brush painting, tie dye or paper cuts.  Students are also introduced to local pioneer artists like Liu Kang and Georgette Chen.  The primary and secondary Art textbooks included pictures and descriptions to introduce students to works by prominent artists, for example, batik painting by Sarkasi Said, Chinese ink painting by Xu Bei Hong and Japanese prints by Ando Hiroshige. Contemporary artworks of local artists such as Ng Eng Teng and Anthony Poon are also featured in the textbooks to foster students’ appreciation of local culture and heritage.

 

     Similarly, through the primary and secondary music curriculum, students develop an awareness of and appreciation for music of various cultures.  They learn about the music of Malay, Chinese, Indian and western cultures and how music is featured in festive and cultural events.  Students learn to sing Asian and local folk songs such as Dayung Sampan (Indonesian), Xiao Bai Chuan (小百船),  Munnaeru Vaalibaa (Singaporean) and Planting Rice (Filipino).  Traditional favourites such as Bengawan Solo (Indonesian), Mo Li Hua (茉莉花), and Semoga Bahagia (Malay) are also included in the recommended list of songs in the music curriculum.

 

     Students also have opportunities in music-making using instruments such as Angklung, kompang and the recorder. Students are exposed to group playing of simple music pieces using the Angklung or recorder.  Through the MOE music package, students are also introduced to the works and lives of local composers

Column: 2356

such as Jeremy Monteiro, Phoon Yew Tien, Mark Chan and Lee Weisong/Lee Sisong brothers. 


     In addition to the art and music curriculum, schools provide arts enrichment programmes to their students.  Almost all schools have leveraged on the Tote Board Arts Grant to bring in quality arts programmes to schools or to bring students out to watch various performances.  These programmes and performances are local productions endorsed under the National Arts Council Arts Education Programme (NAC-AEP).  Schools use this grant to provide opportunity for every student to have access to, and experience a range of art forms, including dance, drama, film, photography and multi-disciplinary arts.

 

     As a result of the very positive response by schools in providing arts enrichment programmes, the Tote Board Arts Grant has been increased from $10,000 to $15,000 per school in 2007.

 

     Moving ahead, all primary schools will further enhance students’ learning in art and music through the Programme for Active Learning (PAL).  PAL would provide additional time for students to explore and enjoy their learning in the Arts and schools plan to extend students’ learning beyond the classroom by organising visits to local artists’ studios, engaging in sculpture walks and watching cultural performances.

 

     Through both the formal and informal school curriculum, students have many learning opportunities and hands-on experiences to develop understanding of as well as an appreciation for arts and culture, both in the local and regional context.

     Ms Audrey Wong Wai Yen (Nominated Member):   Just two supplementary questions.  Thank you, Senior Minister of State,

Column: 2357

for your reply. I welcome the introduction of the PAL programme which will give students more hands-on interactive learning. My two questions are these: firstly, I have met many teachers who feel that they are not sufficiently equipped to teach content about Arts. This is possibly because in the old days in schools, we did not have the benefit of an arts education programme. So, how would the Ministry beef up teacher training?  Secondly, training for arts educators, ie, the artists who themselves carry out programmes in schools.  Are there also plans to enhance their training?

     Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien:  Mr Speaker, I would like to thank the Member for her two supplementary questions. The answer to both questions is "yes", these are the two areas that MOE is focusing its attention on – teachers' quality as well as having the right coaches for our students. The Member will hear a lot more about our plans in the next few days.

Column: 2357

DATA ON PRODUCTIVITY OF PRO-FAMILY ORGANISATIONS

     3.  Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan asked the Minister for Manpower (a) whether he will provide data on the productivity of organisations which have won family-friendly accolades; (b) how does the productivity of firms which embrace pro-family business practices compare with others in the same industry; (c) what is the proportion of employers who embrace pro-family practices like flexi-work options; and (d) whether his Ministry has plans to further encourage employers to grant flexi-work and flexi-schedule options to employees with childcare and eldercare responsibilities.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Manpower (Mr Hawazi Daipi) (for the Minister for Manpower):  Mr Speaker, pro-family business practices, or

Column: 2358

work-life practices, have been shown to contribute to better employee and business performance in many international and local studies.  A study conducted by the Nanyang Business School in 2005 found that firms with more work-life practices enjoyed lower employee turnover.  The study also found that firms with part-time rank-and-file employees directly benefited through higher profitability, employee labour productivity and stock returns.

 

     The same team from Nanyang Business School also conducted a more specific study on Sakae Sushi, which is the flagship brand of Apex-Pal International, winner of the Work-Life Excellence Award in 2006 and 2008.  The study found that employees who benefited from work-life initiatives and who received work-life support from their supervisors and top management, were more engaged in their work and less likely to be absent from work.  These employees tended to perform better at work and provide better customer service.

 

     Employers in Singapore increasingly recognise that good work-life initiatives significantly benefit their organisations.  According to the Ministry of Manpower's Conditions of Employment 2008 report, 27.5% of private-sector employers in Singapore offered flexible work arrangements such as part-time and staggered hours, compared to 20.2% in 2002.  Employee take-up of these flexible work arrangements has also gone up: 7.1% of employees were on such flexible work arrangements, compared with 3.8% in 2002.  In addition, many companies practise informal arrangements which allow their employees to work flexibly on an ad-hoc basis.

 

     Over the years, the promotional approach taken by the Tripartite Committee on Work-Life Strategy has helped to raise awareness of the importance of work-life strategies among companies and

Column: 2359

to broaden the implementation of work-life practices, including flexible work arrangements.  Such flexible work arrangements are beneficial to companies and Singapore's economy because they can help to bring more women back into the workforce, employ or re-employ older workers, and also better attract and retain talent and valued employees.  For these reasons, the Government has put in place the WoW! (Work-Life Works!) Fund and Flexi-Works!, which provide up to a total of $110,000 to help employers kick-start their implementation of flexible work arrangements and other work-life initiatives. 

 

     The Committee will continue to work closely with the tripartite partners to encourage more employers to implement work-life strategies, including flexible work arrangements, to meet the needs of our diverse workforce.

     Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan (Nominated Member):  Thank you for the comprehensive response.  I have three follow-up questions on this.  It is good to note that the Senior Parliamentary Secretary has good news for us – I hope it makes headlines tomorrow.  It is good for employers to note that it is a win-win situation for both company and employees.

 

    My first question is on the take-up rate of flexi-work option at 7.1 %.  While it is an improvement over the last available data, it is still rather low.  I wonder if the Ministry can comment on what are the reported barriers to employees who need this option but hesitate to take it up.  My second question has to do with incentives for companies to embrace positive work-life policies. We understand that these policies are mid to long-term investments in human resource. Therefore, it comes at a cost for the organisation at the onset.  Does the Ministry have plans to roll out incentives to encourage, particularly SMEs, to embrace pro-family policies, for

Column: 2360

example, tax breaks for organisations which practise positive work-life options?

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:  I thank the Member for the questions.  On the 7.1% take-up rate of implementation by companies, I think it is a fairly good result so far.  But, of course, we want to encourage more companies to implement work-life policies so that their workers benefit from it and they themselves, as organisations, can grow better with more engaged employees who can satisfy their customers better.

 

     A number of initiatives have been implemented. As I mentioned earlier, there are already two funds available for companies which want to consider implementing work-life arrangements. One is the WoW! Fund, from which the employers can benefit $10,000 when they implement specific work-life arrangements for their employees. The second is the Flexi-Works! Fund, which is an initiative of the Singapore National Employers Federation and the NTUC to encourage companies to consider devising systems that can help them to employ employees on a part-time flexible basis. We are working on this. The Tripartite Committee will continue to engage the private sector organisations to do this.

 

     On the second question about what incentives can be given to companies which may want to consider implementing work-life initiatives, I think this is a question that MCYS may be able to respond to.

 

 


 

Column: 2360

WAIVER OF MAID LEVY

(Families looking after the elderly)

     4.  Mr Laurence Wee Yoke Thong asked the Minister for Manpower whether the Government will consider reducing or waiving the maid levy for families looking after the frail elderly so that more families can afford maids in the care of the elderly. 

Column: 2361

     Mr Hawazi Daipi (for the Minister for Manpower): Mr Speaker, Sir, since August 2004, families with members aged 65 and above have enjoyed a concessionary foreign domestic worker levy, which is currently $170 a month.  This is significantly less than the regular levy of $265.  Today, close to 38,000 families who have elderly household members and employ foreign domestic workers pay the concessionary levy.  We do not see the need to further reduce the concessionary levy for now.

 

     Foreign domestic workers are not the only care option available to seniors and family caregivers.  For example, there is a network of 22 day care centres island wide, providing care for the elderly when family care givers are at work.  Besides trained care staff, day care centres also provide opportunities for social interaction and group activities which can enhance the quality of life for the elderly.  Day care centres run by the voluntary welfare organisations (VWOs) charge fees starting from $300 a month.  Means-tested subsidies are available to help low-income families.  Elderly who prefer to stay at home can also choose to tap on home-help services, such as meal delivery, personal hygiene care and housekeeping.  For example, daily meal delivery costs about $200 a month.  Similar means-tested subsidies are available to help low-income families.

 

     In addition, the Government supports training in basic care giving skills for informal caregivers, including family members and foreign domestic workers.  Families can tap on MCYS' care giver training grant which is administered by the Centre for Enable Living to offset the cost of such training.

     Mr Laurence Wee Yoke Thong (Nominated Member): Sir, I have two supplementary questions.  As families get smaller, the burden falls on one or two children to look after their frail elderly

Column: 2362

parents.  This cohort of children or generation may also fall into what is known as sandwich generation caring for their young as well.  Getting a maid for the frail elderly is better than placing them in a nursing home if health or medical conditions permit.  Older people prefer to continue living with their families and in familiar surroundings.  Thus, by waiving the levy on the maids looking after frail elderly for families with less than $5,000 household income, more families can afford to even look after grandparents and give them a better quality of life in their twilight years and, more importantly, to help them age gracefully.

 

     Sir, my supplementary question, notwithstanding the reply, is whether the Government would consider the matter again at an opportune time in the future.  Also, can the waiver of maid levy be extended to parents of handicapped children as well?

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:   Sir, the answer is never a no-no.  We can consider all proposals in the future as the population changes.  But for the moment, I think it is not necessary to further reduce the levy because the current system works.  As I mentioned earlier, 38,000 households are already benefiting from the reduced levy for foreign domestic workers.  Let me remind the House again that foreign domestic worker levy is meant to manage the number and the flow of domestic workers into Singapore.  Already we have more than 100,000 foreign domestic workers in Singapore and we will have to learn to manage the number, while we acknowledge the needs of families who may have elderly or young children.

 

    I would also like to remind the House that employing foreign domestic workers is not the only option available.  And I mentioned earlier, MCYS has a scheme to help train care givers, and there are a lot of subsidies and support given by the

Column: 2363

Government to help families manage their elderly at home, including meal delivery.

 

     On handicapped children – generally, we have reduced levy for families with children below 12.  If the handicapped child is below 12 years old, the family can benefit if the family wants to employ a foreign domestic worker.

Column: 2363

PROBLEM OF HOMELESSNESS IN SINGAPORE

     5.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) how serious is the problem of homelessness in Singapore; (b) what measures are being taken to provide shelter to the homeless; (c) what are the primary causes of homelessness; and (d) whether there is any coordination among the various Government agencies to assist the homeless as their problems are usually multi-faceted. 

     The Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan): Sir, in 2009, around 299 persons were referred to MCYS for evaluation of their housing needs.  Most of them had housing difficulties because they were either estranged from their families or their flats had been repossessed or they had sold their flats and had not been able to buy another one.  MCYS works very closely with the Community Development Councils as well as the voluntary welfare organisations to provide comprehensive social and financial assistance to such persons.  There are a variety of housing options available for them depending on their individual circumstances.  For instance, where possible, the HDB will assist them to buy a flat within their means.  For those who need temporary accommodation whilst working on a longer term housing solution, HDB will also refer them to interim rental housing which is managed by the private sector.  If they are still unable to afford their own accommodation and they have no other family

Column: 2364

members who can help, then the HDB will assist them with rental flats under the public rental scheme. 

 

     Persons who need short-term accommodation may also be referred to transitional shelters which are run by the VWOs.  Currently, we have two of them providing such services –  the new HOPE Community Services and the Lakeside Family Centre. 

 

     Apart from housing, social workers will also work with the family to help them resolve their multiple social, financial and employment problems, because the truth is housing is just one dimension of the variety of problems which this family may be confronting.

 

    At the end of 2009, 148 families have been assisted through this scheme, of which 107 families have been discharged to alternative housing arrangements.  The final and last resort for those who are unable to work and have no family members is to be admitted to a Government-funded welfare home for destitute persons.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, families facing financial and housing difficulties should get help as early as possible.  They should call the ComCare hotline at 1800-2220000.  I really want to emphasise that losing a home is one of the most emotionally wrenching exercises I think any family can undergo.  And what all of us need to do is to try our best to prevent them from reaching that stage.  By the time they reach MCYS, I think the problems have already accumulated beyond a point which we should be satisfied with.  So, whilst MCYS will continue to do as much as we can, we will still continue to focus on upstream efforts in order to prevent them reaching that stage.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  Sir, I have a few supplementary questions for

Column: 2365

the Minister.  There have been views expressed that some of the shelters provided, for instance, like the Angsana Home, are not very conducive because they restrict movement and even make it difficult for the homeless to go out to work.  How true is this complaint?

 

     Secondly, I would also like to ask the Minister whether shelters like the Angsana Home is suitable for the homeless with families, especially those with young children, in view of the way in which the shelter is organised.

 

     The third question I would like to ask the Minister is how easy is it really for the homeless to get rental homes or interim housing option, because there are also views expressed that it is actually very difficult to get the rental homes once they have lost their homes.

 

     My final question is to ask the Minister what is the impact of homelessness on the children.  I think the worst is on the children because a lot of feedback I receive is that the children's education is badly affected.  And if that is the case, there will be a cycle of poverty.  We need to prevent that.  What additional measures are put in place by MCYS to assist these children?

     Mr Speaker:  Dr Balakrishnan, you have four minutes.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan:  Four minutes for four supplementary questions! Nevertheless, they are all very valid questions.

 

     On the first point on Angsana Home, or the homes that we run for the destitute, I think any Member here who would like a conducted tour of the home is welcome to do so. And we will show that this is a clean and safe place. It is not luxurious and not comfortable but it

Column: 2366

provides decent housing for people who, as I have said, have no other option, and it is a last resort.

 

     There was a question about whether we restrict the movement of people in Angsana Home. Well, there are some rules in place.  We need some rules in place, first, to ensure the security of the all the other residents.  Secondly, there are many people in that Home who are in there because they have been brought in under the Destitute Persons Act, which means that they may not necessarily be there on a voluntary basis. So there are some rules and there are some restrictions on the movement of people in and out of Angsana Home. Nevertheless, for those who need to work or who need to conduct other matters which require transactions outside the Home, I am sure the management of the Home will work sympathetically and flexibly with them. But I need Members to understand that there is a need for some rules.

 

     The other point which Mdm Halimah brought up is about the options for families. The key thing really is to keep families together. And that is why we always encourage them, wherever possible, to stay with their relatives or if it is not possible, go for interim housing run by the private sector which HDB will refer them to. The other resort is to go to New Hope or to Lakeside Family Centre. These are units which HDB has assigned to these two VWOs.  Again, they are not comfortable because, obviously, they are not totally private in the same context which you would have, if you were in your own home.  The other point is that the reason they are in interim housing is not so much just to provide housing, but rather to give an opportunity for the social workers who are involved with the VWOs to help sort out their problems.  In other words, it requires a family to be prepared to work actively to resolve problems and to seek self-reliance. It is not a long-term permanent form of housing.

 

    

Column: 2367

As the Member has said, therefore, it is not necessarily easy. If someone just comes up and says, "I want housing but don't interfere with me and my life, and sort out all my other social problems," then it will be difficult.

 

     The final point is the most important point. We are most concerned about the impact on children, and that is why I have taken such an active stance to make sure that we do not have people camping out on beaches or parks or void decks, even though these may be safe and indeed sometimes even pleasant areas for adults. These are not good and safe areas for children.  So I have insisted that for any family with children, the children must be put in a proper home. They must continue to go to school. They must continue to get access to good food and good hygiene. And if any family has difficulty providing these things for their children, then MCYS will step in, and we will step in assertively, if need be, in order to protect the children.  So the Member can rest assured that I will do my best to make sure that children do not suffer unnecessarily for the problems which adults sometimes bring upon their own families.

     We are glad that the Government sees the need to cultivate the SME sector and acknowledges the important contributions of SMEs in the Singapore economy. A very welcome initiative in the Budget was the introduction of a Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme. The objective of this new scheme also fulfilled three items of the Budget wish list from the business community, ie, for the Government to provide tax incentives for training, for companies in the service sector to introduce innovative and value-added services as well as for the purchase of machinery to automate processes.  In fact, these tax deductions will now apply not only to research and development, but also to acquisition and registration of intellectual property, design activities, automation through technology or software and the training of employees. This is a major enhancement and we are keen to see the benefit filter through to all enterprises, including the SMEs. 

 

     The rest of my speech will be in three parts, tweaking of the foreign worker levy to manage the supply of foreign workers, productivity as an ultimate goal and affordable land for SMEs and start-ups.

 

    Everyone will agree that Budget 2010 is a visionary Budget, with an eye to investing for the future.  However, some SMEs were disappointed that the Budget

Column: 2390

did not seem to tackle some of their most pressing problems. After a very trying year in 2009, some SMEs have not quite recovered and are still trying to find their feet.  The one area we are not so comfortable with was the realisation that the foreign worker levy will be used as a price mechanism to control the growth of the foreign workforce. While we can understand the rationale for wanting to stem the growth of foreign workers, the hike in foreign worker levy could be quite damaging to growth in the medium and long term for some industries.

 

    Raising productivity is important and ensure that we will not fall behind our other countries. But equally important is the need to keep the cogs of the economic wheel moving and remain cost competitive. How much of our economic growth is attributed to the contribution of foreign workers? Or to ask another question: how has the presence of foreign workers improved Singaporeans' quality of life?  Many foreign workers are here to do back-breaking jobs that no local Singaporeans would like to do. As more local workers become better educated, they are less likely to accept jobs with lower stature.  Currently, 26% of our employed residents possess a university degree and this is expected to increase to 30% by 2015. We are concerned that if the hike in foreign worker levy does cause a cut-back in employment of foreign workers, this could affect operations and growth, if there are insufficient local workers to replace them, or if our productivity does not improve fast enough, especially when we have a low birth rate.

 

    For those companies that need foreign workers, they have no choice but to pay the higher levy. That only means operational costs will increase and they have no choice but to increase the selling price of their goods and services. If we do not have enough manpower and other resources to take on added new orders in

Column: 2391

the world market, we may lose all our customers and business opportunities to our competitors very quickly. Obviously, Singapore is faced with its greatest challenge yet – of how the current workforce can cope with the increased opportunities in the global marketplace, given the clear signal from the Government that employers should wean themselves from the reliance on foreign labour.

 

    Next is productivity. There is going to be a paradigm shift to productivity. When we look at the period over 10 years, this may be more achievable.  But we are, at the moment, more concerned with the near term impact and how this may even erode productivity if not properly managed.  Productivity is not a new concept to Singapore.  The National Productivity Board (NPB) was established in 1972.  It was then merged with the Singapore Institute of Standards and Industrial Research (SISIR) to form the Productivity and Standards Board (PSB) in April 1996.  This was later renamed SPRING Singapore in April 2002, a statutory board which aims to raise productivity to enhance our competitiveness and economic growth. 

 

     Budget 2010 has, however, earmarked productivity as a key strategy and direction to secure Singapore's positioning as an advanced economy, carrying out higher value-added activities and jobs. As the Government has quite rightly said, this is a national effort requiring the inputs and commitments of all Singaporeans. A National Productivity and Continuing Education Council will be set up under the stewardship of Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean to oversee the work of different Government agencies and promote close collaboration amongst the tripartite partners. Since this will be a high level Council, this means that it will provide another level up from the Government agencies. 

 

   

Column: 2392

In view of this, I would like to point out one practical concern. Sometimes, there is some disconnect between Government agencies and the industries, especially the SMEs.  By this, I mean that there is often a gap between the understanding as perceived by Government agencies and what is actually happening on the ground by the industry players.  Hence, real problems faced by the industry can be shoved aside as they may be treated as complaints and grudges rather than actual problems in search of solutions.

 

 

At the same time, the business community needs to communicate their concerns more clearly.  Perhaps, more effort needs to be put in at the level of the Council or the Government agencies to bridge that disconnect and nurture a greater understanding of how the industry actually operates.

 

     Government agencies themselves need to develop a different mindset, engage more with the industry in order to communicate this vision to make sure the implementation is simple and practical. I believe this would be a more effective way instead of a top-down approach in promoting productivity as a national goal.

 

     Productivity and working smart must be the new motto for all Singaporeans. This is a concept that needs to be embraced by all Singaporean employers and workers alike, and requires a great deal of effort from every quarter. The notion of productivity is not always easily quantifiable.  While we can measure the KPI for the manufacturing and construction sectors, how do we actually measure the productivity of the services sector which we are in fact trying to grow in Singapore?  It can be very subjective. Singapore's services industry will be greatly enhanced by the presence of the two new Integrated Resorts (IRs), adding to an already vibrant retail hospitality and F&B landscape in Singapore.  But how do we apply the productivity model in the best way to the services sector?  There is

Column: 2393

no recognised and accepted measurement as services is by nature not as tangible and concrete compared to the manufacturing sector. Should we measure productivity in the services sector by customer experience, product knowledge or service quality? Then, again, these are hardly quantifiable and can at best be based on customer surveys.  From my personal experience and feedback from many others, Singaporeans have a long way to go before we can catch up with the US, Japan and Hong Kong in dealing with customers using the personal touch, a caring attitude and the display of outstanding product knowledge.

 

     Still on the subject of productivity, I would like to suggest another way to boost productivity.  This may have no correlation with wages.  In fact, I strongly believe a happy worker is a productive worker.  Workers need to feel that their contributions are being appreciated and are meaningful.  Workers are human beings, not robots.  And the responsibility of the employer is to do his best to keep them happy and productive.  In fact, in today's Straits Times, front page, it reads: "Bad service? The buck stops with the CEO".  The eventual productivity of the company relies on the joint efforts of the entire team.

 

    Lastly, I would like to touch on affordable land for SMEs and start-ups.  Another recommendation of the Economic Strategies Committee (ESC) that has been taken up by the Budget 2010 is to intensify industrial land use towards more land efficient and higher value added activities.  SMEs and start-ups are also included in the rally to create higher value in every sector of our economy.  In this regard, it is timely to reiterate the need to provide affordable land and rental for SMEs and start-ups.

 

     Budget 2010 acknowledges the importance of SMEs and the Government

Column: 2394

would like to create a dynamic and viable SME sector.  It also encourages a continuous flow of start-ups and new entrants into the economy.  Besides the very thorny issue of manpower, one of the major concerns of the SME is the difficulty of sustaining higher rental costs and being strapped by the unavailability of purpose-built industrial commercial premises.  In the past, Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) played a crucial role in providing industrial land and factory space to support the growth of local enterprises.  Following JTC's withdrawal from the ready-built industrial space market and the divestment of properties to Mapletree in 2008, these properties are now being managed by Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs).  The disadvantage to SMEs is that a REIT manages a property on a purely commercial basis.  SMEs and start-ups no longer have the option of finding affordable industrial commercial premises.  Perhaps, the Government could look at relocating certain industries into purpose-built hubs, besides those already designated for priority clusters like electronics, infocommunication and media, aerospace, marine and cleantech, biomedical and chemical clusters, engineering and logistics.  These could then help accommodate SMEs and start-ups which really need to source affordable industrial and commercial space.

 

     With that, Sir, I support the Budget.

 

1.20 pm

 

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Economic Strategies Committee (ESC) calls for a "clear shift" to sustain our future economic growth on skills, innovation and productivity rather than on expanding the labour force.  Such ideas are not new.

 

     It was recently reported in the Straits Times that notable economists, including University of Michigan Prof. Linda Lim, have questioned Singapore's obsession

Column: 2395

with GDP growth and suggested that more thought be put into whether this growth is "good" and whom it benefits.

 

     The report also stated that "15 years ago, Nobel Prize-winning Princeton economist Paul Krugman caused a mild sensation by warning that while Singapore's headline growth numbers are impressive, its total factor productivity – the efficiency with which people, capital and land are combined to produce goods and services – was among the lowest in the world."

 

     Although this Government has always considered Singapore a small and unique nation, its fiscal measure, so far, has been fairly conservative.  For Budget 2010, the Government is relying again on its own conventional wisdom to address the fundamental problems caused by the implementation of its policies in the past decade.

 

     The "growth at all costs" strategy initiated since the late 90s has resulted in a present state of our economy where low-wage earners are growing dependent on state-funded handouts to subsist and productivity is stagnating at 1% from an influx of cheap foreign labour.

 

     Furthermore, social stress is on the rise and threatening to move our ever-changing society closer to the brink of polarisation.  The level of comfort in our public infrastructure like transport and healthcare is also declining upon a population spike of almost a million people in the last decade, with 75% of the increase arriving the last four years alone.

 

     Although the Finance Minister has said in his Budget speech that the impressive growth of the past decade achieved with the help of foreign workers was not a strategy of "growth at all costs" but of growing our economy to raise Singaporean incomes, the increase in

Column: 2396

median income per household member from 2005 to 2008, cited by the Minister, tells only part of the story.

 

     The Report on Wages in Singapore for 2008, released by the Ministry of Manpower, shows clearly the wages of lowest-paid group of workers have remained stagnant for a decade.  The wage gap between the higher-skilled occupational group and the lowest-paid group has also widened in 2008 from a decade ago.

 

     Sir, when the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) has to be revised upward and the qualifying monthly income limit increased to $1,700 to ensure low-wage earners are not left behind in our foreigner-dependent economy, does that not raise an alarm in the Government about the meagre salary that our low-wage workers are getting?

 

     The growth strategy adopted by the Government for the past 10 years has definitely not made these Singaporean workers feel any sense of progress with the nation.

 

     Minister Mentor's speech to the residents of Tanjong Pagar probably summed up the "growth at all costs" strategy best.  He said, "Between the two, growth as against no growth?  I have no doubt we made the right decision: growth, whatever the inconveniences of competition of space, buses, MRTs, even schools – but we always give preference to our own citizens." 

 

     That qualification at the end of Minister Mentor Lee's remark is cold comfort to Singaporeans struggling to make ends meet because there is also the competition for jobs. 

 

     This year's Budget is touted as a fiscal measure for Singapore to move "Towards an Advance Economy" with "Superior Skills, Quality Jobs and Higher Incomes". 

Column: 2397

The three key elements in this year's Budget are "Raising Productivity", "Growing Globally Competitive Companies" and "Including All Singaporeans in Growth". 

 

     Stripping away the rhetoric, the fiscal policies put forth by the Government for 2010 are neither innovative nor groundbreaking enough to reflect the uphill task of making Singapore an advance economy and, more importantly, less dependent on foreign workers.

 

     I am not concerned with the quantum of the Budget.  It is the initiatives that worry me, in particular the initiative in raising productivity and income.

 

     First, let me touch on raising productivity. To undo years of dependency on cheap foreign labour and to grow the economy through higher productivity is a difficult journey.  The impressive GDP growth of 5% a year in the last decade, as reported by the ESC, was achieved through the expansion of our workforce, specifically with a lot of help from a rapidly growing non-Singaporean workforce.

 

     Years of economic expansion have not done much to help low-wage earners move up the value chain, as the labour statistics had shown.  Productivity has stagnated at 1% for the past decade.

 

     Sir, Singaporean workers are constantly asked to up-skill, re-skill, multi-skill, be cheaper, better and faster.  On top of all that, they must also work longer and the latest demand on our workforce is to work smarter as well.  I must say this Government is highly productive at squeezing every drop of effort and energy from our workers to achieve its desired GDP numbers.

 

     But are Singaporean workers that hard to manage?  Are they so lazy or resistant

Column: 2398

to change that they have to be constantly reminded to up-skill, re-skill and multi-skill?  Are they so expensive and unproductive that NTUC has to initiate a "Cheaper, Better, Faster" rally call to all companies and workers?

 

     In case the Government has forgotten, this workforce has stood by Singapore since our independence.  Singaporean workers have given their best years to grow the economy.  They have contributed their blood, sweat and tears to nation-building before the floodgates were opened for foreign workers to continue to satisfy the Government's appetite for high GDP growth.

 

     While the Government has been very pro-business all the while, it should spare a thought for what our workers want out of a healthy economy.  Singaporean workers' perspective of employment is simple about bread and butter issues.  Can the wages they make meet their expenditure after deducting for transport, meals, CPF, housing, medical fees, etc?

 

     Thus, wages for workers, especially for the low-income group, must go up when the economy is doing well.  This is just not the case as the 2008 Report on Wages in Singapore has shown.

 

     The Minister said in his Budget speech that "raising skills and productivity is the only viable way we can achieve higher wages and is the best way to help citizens with low incomes".

 

     Sir, I want to state clearly the responsibility and enabling factor for helping citizens with low income to achieve higher wages rest squarely on the shoulders of the Government.  It should not attempt to link the cause of low wages in our healthy economy on the low productivity of our workers.

 

     It is easy to blame our local workforce for low productivity but who opened the

Column: 2399

gates to allow foreign workers to flood the labour market in the first place?  The easy access to cheap foreign labour offers little incentive for companies to up their productivity and this is stated in the ESC report.  The Government has to assume some responsibility for the low productivity registered in the last decade.

 

     Low-wage workers have lived with low productivity and high growth for the past 10 years with little improvement to their incomes.  I made the same comment at last year's Budget debate speech.  Meanwhile, this Government has taken every opportunity to bask in the glory of having brought our tiny economy from third world to first.  But how long more must our low-wage workers wait to enjoy a first world pay?  Must they wait until our productivity reaches 2%-3%?

 

     Low-wage workers have every reason to be concerned with this productivity drive.  The Minister has said that the Government's goal is to grow our productivity by 2%-3% per year over the next decade.  Only then, real income can go up by one-third in 10 years.

 

     Does this mean that the Government expects low-wage workers to wait another 10 years for something that may not happen as we have witnessed the last 10 years?  Low-wage workers do not have the incentive to go for training after training.  If they have any time to spare, they will probably take on a second job to supplement their meagre income.

 

     Therefore, the question the Government should answer is, why after decades of promoting productivity and skills training, and despite that we have achieved 5% productivity growth in the 1980s and about 3% in the 1990s, we are back to the same call again?

 

     The next question is, why manual workers like cleaners and garbage

Column: 2400

collectors in developed economies are paid so much more than their counterparts in Singapore?  Are the cleaners there more productive than ours or do these developed economies have more compassionate and effective policies to ensure workers at the bottom of the economic ladder do enjoy a decent and dignified life?

 

     With the new emphasis on productive, it seems the Government is suggesting that workers with low income have only themselves to blame because of their low productivity and low skills.  The call to workers to up-skill, re-skill and multi-skill may not yield the desired results as well.

 

     I know of machine operators in the construction sector who participated in MOM's safety course and other skills recognition programmes,

 

 

only to end up losing their jobs to foreigners or have their wages depressed because foreign workers are prepared to work for lower pay and longer hours. 

 

     Sir, I will move on to the issue of dependency on foreign workers in our economy.  The Government's intention to use a price mechanism to manage the growth of foreign workers will probably not affect large profitable companies.  As you can read in the newspaper,  most of the concerns came from SMEs.  It will probably create a divided economy with profitable companies hiring foreign workers as per normal and struggling companies relocating or downsizing.  The price mechanism will not work too if the total cost of hiring a foreign worker, with a levy thrown in, is below a decent living wage for a Singaporean worker.  Most companies will have to hire foreigners because no Singaporean workers will apply.  The price mechanism is also opened to abuses.  MOM has stated it will step up monitoring and enforcement efforts against employers who try to pass on the levy to the foreign workers.  This whole exercise could just end up fattening 

Column: 2401

the Government's coffer with little results to show in controlling the ever-expanding foreign workforce.  With the Government's determination to expand our economy using productivity growth so that Singaporean workers can finally achieve real wage growth and income level comparable to developed economies, it should take the bold step to remove the foreign workers' levy completely.  The Government should just use the dependency ratio to control the growth of foreign workers in Singapore.  Dependency ratio can be refined by industry sectors as well as size of the company to allow foreign workers to supplement local manpower when it is necessary.  The Government can decide on the dependency ratio in consultation with the industry and set realistic targets on productivity growth in different industrial sectors by gradually reducing the ratio.  The savings in foreign workers' levy can then be used by companies  to provide employment for local workers when the dependency ratio is reduced, upgrade the production process or send local workers for training to upgrade their skills. 

 

     The dependency ratio will force employers to look harder how to re-skill and make Singaporean workers productive instead of looking to relatively low cost foreign workers as an option to compete in the market.  It becomes an incentive for the employer to find ways to raise productivity in order to stay competitive.  The new system proposed by the Government of using price mechanism and a tiered system levy based on the proportion of foreigners on the payroll to address the dependency on foreign workers is too complicated.  It does not look like a system designed to control the growth of foreign workers but as a source of revenue for the Government. 

 

     Sir, it was reported in the news that there were about 856,000 work permit

Column: 2402

holders in Singapore as at December.  Taking away 196,000 domestic helpers, we are left with 660,000 work permit holders.  A $10 to $30 per month increase in levy will translate to an additional $79 million to $238 million per year in work permit levy for the Government. 

 

     If I use the low-end of the work permit levy, which is $150 per month, and multiply that by 660,000 workers, the Government is taking in about $1.2 billion per year in work permit levy.  If I use the concessionary domestic helper levy which is $170 per month and multiply that by 196,000 workers, the total levy collected by this Government for all 856,000 work permit holders is a conservative estimate of $1.6 billion per year before any increase scheduled on 1st July.  I have not even added the levy for the 82,000 S-pass holders.  This brings me to the next issue of helping workers upgrade through Continuing Education and Training (CET) and innovation.  Although CET and innovation are key components  to boost productivity, the emphasis should be on innovation.  To achieve an "Advanced Economy" with "Superior Skills, Quality Jobs and Higher Income" requires innovation through research and development, redesigning work method and machinery, information technology and automation.  Productivity will be a natural by-product of innovation.  While a total of $5.5 billion is set aside to boost productivity over five years, only $1.5 billion is going into R&D via the National Research Fund.  The Gross Expenditure of R&D stood at 2.8% in 2008.  The ESC has recommended raising that to 3.8% but the Minister highlighted Finland and its R&D spending as an example of putting money to good use.  Finland spent about 3.4% of its GDP on R&D at the end of 2000.

    

     Companies such as Sony, LG, Samsung, Acer and Canon are private and highly innovative multinationals. I can hardly name any private entity here that

Column: 2403

comes close to what these companies have achieved.  Of course, some of you may say we have Creative, the sound card maker.  If you read its story, you will find that Government has very little to do with Creative's growth and success as well.  I believe we do have a lot of room to improve with R&D funding and nurturing SMEs into global companies.  I urge the Government to take bold steps now rather than a measured approach to make that vision a reality.  We should raise the R&D funding and involve SMEs in nation building as much as we can.  Let me now move on to continuing education and training and our ageing society.

 

     The Minister has said that the Government will place additional  emphasis on our older low-wage workers by providing them the needed support to enhance their skills and continue to be valued in the workplace.  While all these CET activities are good for low-wage workers, continuing education does not always have to be work and wage-related.  As Singapore is an ageing society, we must include older Singaporeans, working or retired, in the masterplan towards becoming an advanced economy.  While CET may serve a purpose for older workers, an adult continuing an education programme should be initiated to cater to the needs of the retirees.  Learning as we know is a lifelong process.  We should develop a community college for citizens of all ages, especially older Singaporeans who enrich themselves in course not related to their work.  The college can have low or minimum entry requirement, courses are totally modular.  A senior citizen can earn credit towards a degree or simply for self-enrichment.  Entrepreneurs can come in any age group.  For an ageing society like Singapore, we should not even have any preconceived ideas on the limitation on what older Singaporeans can do to help build our economy.

 

     In conclusion, Sir, looking at the revenue the Government collects every

Column: 2404

year from the foreign workers levy, it has a moral obligation to ensure our low-wage workers are not left behind.  Ten years is a long wait for low-wage earners to move up the economic ladder.  Asking these people to wait another decade for that to happen and to depend on State handouts in the interim is wrong.  I again urge the Government, as what I did at the last Budget Debate, to work harder to up the wages of the workers soonest possible rather than wait for productivity to improve because that is also conditional upon the affordability of companies to pay the increase in levy.  There is no easy way to success.  I believe Singaporeans understand that very well.  Singaporeans have shown resilience and endured the economic hardship and discomfort with the influx of foreign workers for the past 10 years.  On top of that, Singaporeans have to cope with depressed income and rising cost of living such as high utility cost.  It is only fair that the Government starts looking at how to uplift the lives of Singaporeans and make them more pleasant.  This is a timely wake-up call to the Government as general election is getting nearer.

 

 

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Masagos Zulkifli B M M) (In Malay): [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A*.] My parliamentary colleague, Mr Liang, has touched on his aspiration for our economy to join the main league economies. I was driving last Friday and heard the news on the BBC channel that Barclay’s Premier League football club Portsmouth is declared bankrupt. In fact, by just entering that League, a football club can be very wealthy. A club can receive £7 million in transfer fees and broadcasting rights, not counting other income. This is even if Portsmouth is one of the bottom clubs within the Premier League and it can still potentially build its assets in terms of money, players and coaches. However, no matter how high is its income,

Column: 2405

Portsmouth has spent more than what it can earn. Hence, it has to suffer the consequences of its own actions. As a result of being bankrupt, the club will lose its Premier League status and subsequently, lose the right to earn further income as well as the chance to develop.


     It struck me how a segment of our community – and I am not saying that it is everyone – can fail in their life in Singapore, even though they live in country that is rich, prosperous and abundant with economic opportunities, just by choosing the wrong path. For example, recently, we see many reports on the beach community phenomenon – which does not refer to those who like relaxing at the beach, but are stranded there because they lost their homes. This situation is often portrayed in the media as associated with the Malay community, which always faces challenges and is described as a community left behind. Some people swiftly attribute it to the lack of ability among the leadership or Government to solve the problem, and so on. What is clear is that even though the Government and community leadership will, and must, help them to have a roof over their heads and be able to rise again, we must not forget the real cause as to why they are stranded there, and not be quick to point fingers.


     There are a few similar cases where I am trying to assist. Families facing such misfortune are coming to meet me during the Meet-the-People Session (MPS). After I obtained enough information from the HDB, I was often left puzzled as to why many of them have to suffer such a fate. But what is clear is that many cases are caused by them making incorrect or slow decisions. Many of them have already made substantial profits by selling their flats. Some bought their flats in the early 1970s for only $7,000 and then sold it

Column: 2406

for $200,000. Some reaped this kind of profits not only once, but twice. However, the sales profits that are reaped only when the economy is good and allows homes to be sold at a good profit, subsequently does not bring happiness to them and some of them suffer.


     There are those among them who buy new homes that are more expensive and beyond their means. Many do not take into account whether they can continue paying for it. Some invest a lot of money to beautify their house. Some even distribute the sales proceeds to their children, because they love them so much and also to gain favour in the hope that the children will take care of them when they no longer have a house. Some even marry again! When problems occur, whether because they were retrenched or have chronic illness, they do not know how to quickly solve their problems. For instance, they face an increasing loan interest. Eventually, they are not only unable to pay the principal loan, but the interest is now almost equal to the principal loan. Those who no longer own homes, because they were thrown out due to family conflicts, are now stranded at the beach.


     This is the Portsmouth Football Club syndrome that is afflicting parts of our community.  They should have been prosperous due to the high asset value of their homes that will continue to increase. That asset should have been their investment for old age or for their children to fulfil their ambitions through continuing education, but due to incorrect life choices, the opportunities are gone and they are removed from the successful group and from the main league. What is obvious is that each issue or consequence is not due to a wrong Government policy, but because it is a game between Government policy and individual choice, and sometimes, the assistance available from the community.


    

Column: 2407

This is my concern when I listened to the speech by the Minister for Finance, Mr Tharman. He promised that after taking into account inflation, income will increase by a third within a decade and it can be achieved if we can increase productivity by upgrading skills through continuous education. The Government will also spend billions of dollars to enhance industries, thus increasing job opportunities that are of high quality and promise better pay. To be sure, this Budget is a milestone budget which will shape the economy in the future.


     There are two groups that I am concerned about in the Government’s effort to reshape our economy. The first group is those who I think will succeed in seizing opportunities to upgrade themselves. This group will more or less be able to make their lives more stable. I hope they will be able to learn lessons from the group who lost their homes due to lack of knowledge in investing the profits that they accumulated from selling their houses. We must learn and be aware of what really happened to those who lost such valuable assets. I do not wish to teach them how to spend their money more wisely. I just want to remind everyone, that even with the best Government policies, individuals must make the right choices. This is especially so with the current economic condition that is chaotic and uncertain.

 

     Similarly, their ability to earn income will be unequal and unstable within this uncertain global economic climate currently. In this situation, we must have a savings system that we can use when times are hard. We should not lose our hard earned assets that should have guaranteed a good future. We should not lose those assets due to mistakes, just because we want to try living the good life. I would also like to ask the Government to take steps so that the assets that were just built by certain segments of society can be kept in the

Column: 2408

form of savings or houses, maybe by re-introducing the system of returning the money from loans to the CPF before returning it to the banks, while the profits made may need to be locked up for the time being. With this, hopefully, the community that has just attained success will stay in the main league and is not relegated, just because of wrong life choices. With this, a community that has just progressed will continue progressing, and thus reduces the number of people who still need help to build their lives.

 

     The Government will also spend $2.5 billion to establish Continuing Education and Training. I hope that this fund will be distributed in the best way to build up the second group. This group includes those who are still trapped in the lowest rung of society; still unable to enter the main league. This is the group that is still left behind and even though the Government has already increased assistance to them, in the form of the WIS or subsidies like U-Save, they still have a lack of vision and are gripped by the pressures of daily life. Sometimes, it is due to too much physical labour to feed their families. But I disagree with Mr Low that this is the only reason they will not be able to seize future opportunities. Many of them have family members arguing at home. The house is not peaceful and the children are not taken care of properly. There are also many cases of fathers or husbands in jail. In this matter, I hope that the Government will still pay attention to the issues that they face, as they are already left behind. And with the renewed direction of the economy, we do not want them to be left further behind in the coming years.

 

     To solve the problems I mentioned earlier, I would like to suggest that the Government further strengthen the bodies that often help the needy, who are mostly from the minority groups, and I suggest that the Government increase funding or provide relevant information to self-help bodies like MENDAKI and SINDA. This is

Column: 2409

important because such bodies can broadcast information about upgrading programmes to those who are affected, through suitable language and cultural approach. Government bodies should also adjust their assessment when measuring the success of their policies. For example, it is often said that if 80% of a specific group can benefit from it, it is enough to celebrate the Government body’s effort as a success.
